title: What happens to the energy by two electromagnetic waves when they undergo destructive interference? - Quora

This is a question I once wrote about extensively in another forum. I don’t recall where it was, but I bet Google does… ah, here we go: What happens to the energy when waves perfectly cancel each other? The bottom line is this: If you look at the full context — the broader surrounding region in space — of any example of destructive interference, you will find that what is really happening is that energy is being reflected away from the region of destructive interference. The energy is not destroyed; you have simply built a mirror! In fact, that is how real mirrors work. The interaction of electromagnetic waves with the free (“Fermi surface”) electrons of the metal creates reciprocal fields, a sort of rebound effect, that cancel out the waves of the light itself. At a first level of analysis, especially if you focus only on the thin layer of metal in which these fields cancel each other out, it looks like destructive interference has destroyed the photon, violating conservation of energy. But as soon as you pull out to the broader perspective, you realize that all these self-canceling wave really did was create a barrier through which the photons cannot travel. So they instead reflect, forming a mirror. This is always true in cases of destructive interference; the energy is always reflected away from the region of destructive interference, and into some other region of space. Energy conservation is not tricked this easily!
